facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 299 of 1964 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 299 of 1964.

facts.text: The appeal is from the judgment and order dated September 26, 1961 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 620 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 26, 1961 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 620 of 1957.

facts.text: P. Goyal appeared for the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: P. Goyal, for the appellants.

facts.text: C. Misra appeared for respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: C. Misra, for the respondent No. 1.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on April 15, 1964 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: April 15, 1964. The judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-

facts.text: The appellants are the four original defendants in a suit for pre-emption filed by the first respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by certificate from the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad the appellants are the four original defendants in a suit for pre-emption filed by the first respondent.

facts.text: Kaiseri Begam respondent No. 2 sold a plot and two houses in mohalla Gher Abdul Rahman Khan, Qasba Milak, Tehsil Milak, District Rampur, to the appellants on December 4, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Kaiseri Begam  respondent No. 2  sold a plot and two houses in mohalla Gher Abdul Rahman Khan, Qasba Milak, Tehsil Milak, District Rampur, to the appel- lants on December 4, 1953.

facts.text: The first respondent Labh Singh owned the adjacent house.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent Labh Singh owned the adjacent house and he claimed pre-emption on the ground of vicinage after making the usual demands.

facts.text: Labh Singh claimed pre-emption on the ground of vicinage after making the usual demands.

anchor.surface_text: and he claimed pre-emption on the ground of vicinage after making the usual demands.

facts.text: The suit was filed by Labh Singh in the court of Munsif, Rampur.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was filed by Labh Singh in the companyrt of Munsif, Rampur who by his judgment dated September 25, 1955

facts.text: Munsif Rampur by judgment dated September 25, 1955 held that there was a general custom of pre-emption in the town of Milak.

anchor.surface_text: who by his judgment dated September 25, 1955 held that there was a general custom of pre-emption in the town of Milak.

facts.text: Munsif held that Labh Singh was entitled to pre-empt and had performed the Talabs.

anchor.surface_text: He also held that Labh Singh was entitled to preempt and had performed the Talabs.

facts.text: Munsif dismissed the suit because the sale did not include a strip of land 3 feet 6 inches wide between Labh Singh's house and the property sold.

anchor.surface_text: He, however, dismissed the suit because the sale did number include a strip of land 3 feet 6 inches wide between Labh Singhs house and the property sold.

facts.text: District Judge, Rampur allowed the appeal by Labh Singh and dismissed the cross-objections by the present appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge, Rampur allowed the appeal and dismissed the cross-objections.

facts.text: The appellants filed a second appeal in the High Court of Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then filed a second appeal in the High Court of Allahabad.

facts.text: Mr. Justice V. D. Bhargava referred the question of constitutionality of pre-emption right to a Division Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Justice V. D. Bhargava, who heard the appeal, referred the following question to a Division Bench-- Whether after companying into operation of the right of pre-emption

facts.text: The Division Bench held that the law relating to pre-emption on the ground of vicinage was saved by clause 5 of Art. 19 and was not void under Art. 13 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Divisional Bench held that the law relation to pre-emp- tion on the ground of vicinage was saved by clause  5  of Art. 19 and was number void under Art. 13 of the Constitution.

facts.text: The High Court dismissed the second appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In view of this answer, the second appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: The High Court certified the case for appeal to the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, certified the case and the present appeal has been filed.

holdings.text: The law of pre-emption based on vicinage is void as it imposes unreasonable restrictions on the right to acquire, hold and dispose of property under Art. 19(1)(f), and this holding from Bhau Ram applies equally to customary law

anchor.surface_text: The question which was posed by Mr. Justice V. D. Bhargava was considered by this Court in connection with s.10 of the Rewa State Pre-emption Act, 1946 in Bhau Ram v. B. Baijnath Singh  1 . This Court held by majority that the law of pre- emption on the ground of vicinage imposed unreasonable restrictions on the right to acquire, hold and to dispose of property guaranteed by Art. 19 1  f  of the Constitution and was void. It was pointed out that it placed restrictions both on the vendor and on the vendee and there was numberadvantage to the general public and. that the only reason given in support of it, that it prevented persons belonging to different religions, races or castes from acquiring property in any area peopled by persons of other religious, races or castes, companyld number be companysidered reasonable in view of Art. 15 of the Constitution. If this ruling applies the present appeal must succeed. Mr. C. Misra, who appears for Labh Singh attempts to distinguish Bhau Rams case 1 . He companytends that the earlier case was companycerned with a legislative measure whereas the.  1  1962 Supp. 3 S.C.R. 724. present case of pre-emption arises from custom. He refers to the decision in Digambar Singh v. Ahmad Said Khan 1  where the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council has given the early history of the law of pre-emption in village company- munities in India and points out that the law of pre-emption had its origin in the Mohammedan Law and was the result, some times, of a companytract between the sharers in a village. Mr. Misra companytends that Arts. 14 and 15 are addressed to the State as defined in Art. 12 and are number applicable to custom or companytract as neither, according to him, amounts to law within the definition given in Art. 13 3  b  of the Consti- tution. He submits that the ruling of this Court does number companyer the present case and that it is necessary to companysider the question of the validity of the customary law of pre- emption based on vicinage. It is hardly necessary to go into ancient law to discover the sources of the law of pre-emption whether customary or the result of companytract or statute. In so far as statute law is companycerned Bhau Rams case 2   decides that a law of pre- emption based on vicinage is void. The reasons given by this Court to hold statute law void apply equally to a custom.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows majority holding in Bhau Ram that vicinage pre-emption statute imposes unreasonable restrictions not saved by Art.19(5) nor justified under Art.15; reasons extend equally to custom without distinction

holdings.text: Custom or usage having the force of law is affected by Part III of the Constitution including Art.19(1)(f) as it constitutes 'law' under Art.13

anchor.surface_text: re- emption based on vicinage is void. The reasons given by this Court to hold statute law void apply equally to a custom. The only question thus is whether custom as such is affected by Part III dealing with fundamental rights and particularly Art. 19 1  f . Mr. Misra ingeniously points out in this companynection that Art. 13 1  deals with all laws in force and custom is number included in the definition of the phrase laws in force in clause  3  b  of Art. 13.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects distinction between statute and custom; Art.13(1) applies to customs having force of law via definition of 'law' in Art.13(3)(a)

holdings.text: The definition of 'law' in Art.13(3)(a) which includes custom or usage having force of law applies to Art.13(1); the inclusive definition of 'laws in force' in Art.13(3)(b) amplifies but does not exclude it
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation: 'law' def in 3(a) reads into cl.(1); 3(b) inclusive amplification only; purposive: avoids anomaly of customs immune to fundamental rights and inconsistency with cl.(2); policy consequences compel inclusion

anchor.surface_text: The question which was posed by Mr. Justice V. D. Bhargava was considered by this Court in connection with s.10 of the Rewa State Pre-emption Act, 1946 in Bhau Ram v. B. Baijnath Singh  1 . This Court held by majority that the law of pre- emption on the ground of vicinage imposed unreasonable restrictions on the right to acquire, hold and to dispose of property guaranteed by Art. 19 1  f  of the Constitution and was void. It was pointed out that it placed restrictions both on the vendor and on the vendee and there was numberadvantage to the general public and. that the only reason given in support of it, that it prevented persons belonging to different religions, races or castes from acquiring property in any area peopled by persons of other religious, races or castes, companyld number be companysidered reasonable in view of Art. 15 of the Constitution. If this ruling applies the present appeal must succeed. Mr. C. Misra, who appears for Labh Singh attempts to distinguish Bhau Rams case 1 . He companytends that the earlier case was companycerned with a legislative measure whereas the.  1  1962 Supp. 3 S.C.R. 724. present case of pre-emption arises from custom. He refers to the decision in Digambar Singh v. Ahmad Said Khan 1  where the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council has given the early history of the law of pre-emption in village company- munities in India and points out that the law of pre-emption had its origin in the Mohammedan Law and was the result, some times, of a companytract between the sharers in a village. Mr. Misra companytends that Arts. 14 and 15 are addressed to the State as defined in Art. 12 and are number applicable to custom or companytract as neither, according to him, amounts to law within the definition given in Art. 13 3  b  of the Consti- tution. He submits that the ruling of this Court does number companyer the present case and that it is necessary to companysider the question of the validity of the customary law of pre- emption based on vicinage. It is hardly necessary to go into ancient law to discover the sources of the law of pre-emption whether customary or the result of companytract or statute. In so far as statute law is companycerned Bhau Rams case 2   decides that a law of pre- emption based on vicinage is void.
